In this section, we evaluate the effectiveness of X-GGM key components and compare the proposed X-GGM scheme with state-of-the-art approaches on two standard VQA OOD benchmarks, \ie, VQA-CP v2Â (Agrawal
etÂ al., 2018) and GQA-OODÂ (Kervadec etÂ al., 2020).
TableÂ 1 reports the statistics of experimental datasets.

R-GGM / N-GGM / X-GGM vs. Baseline.
To improve the OOD generalization ability of the cross-modality representation ğ’™ğ’™{\bm{x}} yielded by ğ’±â€‹ğ’¬â€‹ğ’œâ„›ğ’±ğ’¬subscriptğ’œâ„›\mathcal{{VQA_{R}}}, besides training the baseline VQA model using the full X-GGM scheme, R-GGM and N-GGM can also work independently.
Therefore, we consider comparisons between the ablated components (#1, #2, #5) and the Baseline, \ie, LXMERT (LX.) in TableÂ 2 to evaluate the respective effects of R-GGM, N-GGM, and X-GGM.
Specifically, â–¶â–¶\blacktriangleright LX. \vs#1 (only using R-GGM in the training process).
â–¶â–¶\blacktriangleright LX. \vs#2 (only using N-GGM in the training process).
â–¶â–¶\blacktriangleright LX. \vs#5 (using the full X-GGM scheme that executes R-GGM and N-GGM at a ratio of Î·ğœ‚\eta in the training process).
TableÂ 2 shows the results on VQA-CP v2 â€œOtherâ€ and GQA-OOD.
LX. \vs#5 demonstrates the effectiveness of X-GGM.
LX. \vs#1 / #2 illustrates that the single R-GGM / N-GGM can also effectively improve the OOD generalization performance of the baseline VQA model.

R-GGM / N-GGM vs. X-GGM.
In each training iteration, X-GGM randomly executes R-GGM or N-GGM to improve the OOD generalization ability of the baseline VQA model.
To explore the importance of R-GGM and N-GGM to the full training scheme (X-GGM), as shown in TableÂ 2 (#1, #2, #5), we conduct the following comparisons:
â–¶â–¶\blacktriangleright #1 \vs#5,
and â–¶â–¶\blacktriangleright #2 \vs#5.
The results in TableÂ 2 indicate that R-GGM is more effective than N-GGM for the X-GGM scheme in boosting the OOD performance of the baseline VQA model (LXMERT) on both VQA-CP v2 â€œOtherâ€ and GQA-OOD.
This is mainly because the gradient instability caused by the noise introduction in N-GGM is larger than that in R-GGM.
Specifically, the noise vector dimensions introduced into R-GGM and N-GGM are Noâ€‹(Noâˆ’1)/2=630subscriptğ‘ğ‘œsubscriptğ‘ğ‘œ12630N_{o}(N_{o}-1)/2=630 and NoÃ—d=27,648subscriptğ‘ğ‘œğ‘‘27648N_{o}\times d=27,648, respectively.

Gradient Distribution Consistency Loss.
To evaluate the effectiveness of the gradient distribution consistency loss â„’âˆ‡subscriptâ„’âˆ‡\mathcal{L}_{\nabla} in alleviating the unstable gradient issue, we compare the respective effects of â„’âˆ‡subscriptâ„’âˆ‡\mathcal{L}_{\nabla} and â„’Dsubscriptâ„’ğ·\mathcal{L}_{D}.
The KL-Divergence loss â„’Dsubscriptâ„’ğ·\mathcal{L}_{D} is also an adversarial loss.
The experimental settings are shown in TableÂ 2 (#3, #4, #5).
More specifically,
âŠ³âŠ³\vartriangleright #ğŸ¥3\mathsf{3}: only using â„’Dsubscriptâ„’ğ·\mathcal{L}_{D} as the adversarial loss to train the baseline VQA model (LXMERT) with the X-GGM scheme,
âŠ³âŠ³\vartriangleright #ğŸ¦4\mathsf{4}: only using â„’âˆ‡subscriptâ„’âˆ‡\mathcal{L}_{\nabla} as the adversarial loss to train the baseline VQA model with the X-GGM scheme,
and âŠ³âŠ³\vartriangleright #ğŸ§5\mathsf{5}: using a weighted sum of â„’âˆ‡subscriptâ„’âˆ‡\mathcal{L}_{\nabla} and â„’Dsubscriptâ„’ğ·\mathcal{L}_{D} as the adversarial loss to train the baseline VQA model with the X-GGM scheme.
The comparisons between #3, #4, and #5 on VQA-CP v2 â€œOtherâ€ and GQA-OOD in TableÂ 2 illustrate that both â„’Dsubscriptâ„’ğ·\mathcal{L}_{D} and â„’âˆ‡subscriptâ„’âˆ‡\mathcal{L}_{\nabla} are effective for training the baseline VQA model with the X-GGM scheme.
However, â„’âˆ‡subscriptâ„’âˆ‡\mathcal{L}_{\nabla} performs better than â„’Dsubscriptâ„’ğ·\mathcal{L}_{D}, demonstrating the effectiveness of â„’âˆ‡subscriptâ„’âˆ‡\mathcal{L}_{\nabla} in alleviating unstable gradient updates in graph adversarial learning.

Ablation Studies.
The results in TableÂ 2 indicate that a single R-GGM or N-GGM can also effectively improve the OOD generalization ability of baseline VQA models in addition to the full X-GGM scheme, and â„’âˆ‡subscriptâ„’âˆ‡\mathcal{L}_{\nabla} is more effective than â„’Dsubscriptâ„’ğ·\mathcal{L}_{D} for alleviating the unstable gradient issue when training the baseline VQA model with the X-GGM scheme.
To further illustrate the effectiveness of â„’âˆ‡subscriptâ„’âˆ‡\mathcal{L}_{\nabla} when training the Baseline with single R-GGM or N-GGM, as shown in TableÂ 6 (#6, #7, #8, #9), we conduct more ablated experiments.
Specifically,
âŠ³âŠ³\vartriangleright #6 only using â„’âˆ‡subscriptâ„’âˆ‡\mathcal{L}_{\nabla} as the adversarial loss to train the baseline VQA model (LXMERT) with the R-GGM.
âŠ³âŠ³\vartriangleright #7 only using â„’Dsubscriptâ„’ğ·\mathcal{L}_{D} as the adversarial loss to train the Baseline with the R-GGM.
âŠ³âŠ³\vartriangleright #8 only using â„’âˆ‡subscriptâ„’âˆ‡\mathcal{L}_{\nabla} as the adversarial loss to train the Baseline with the N-GGM.
âŠ³âŠ³\vartriangleright #9 only using â„’Dsubscriptâ„’ğ·\mathcal{L}_{D} as the adversarial loss to train the Baseline with the N-GGM.
The results on VQA-CP v2 â€œOtherâ€ and GQA-OOD are shown in TableÂ 6, which consistently illustrate that â„’âˆ‡subscriptâ„’âˆ‡\mathcal{L}_{\nabla} is more effective than â„’Dsubscriptâ„’ğ·\mathcal{L}_{D} when training the baseline VQA model with a single R-GGM or N-GGM.

references:
In the proposed X-GGM scheme, Graph Encoder is a general block utilized to aggregate node information and encode relationships between nodes.
That is, architecture differences between different Graph Encoders can not markedly affect the performance ofÂ X-GGM to OOD generalization.
To demonstrate that the X-GGM scheme is robust for different variants of Graph Encoder, we consider three prevailing Graph Neural Networks (\ie, GCNÂ (Kipf and Welling, 2016a), GINÂ (Xu
etÂ al., 2018), and GATÂ (VeliÄkoviÄ‡ etÂ al., 2017)) and set the number of their layers Nlsubscriptğ‘ğ‘™N_{l} to 1 and 2.
From the results on VQA-CP v2 â€œOtherâ€ and GQA-OOD shown in TableÂ 3, we can observe that there is only a slight difference between the OOD performance of different Graph Encoder variants.
However, all of these variants have achieved dramatic improvements in OOD performance compared with the baseline VQA model (LXMERT).
The results demonstrate that X-GGM is agnostic to Graph Encoder and is robust for different Graph Encoders.

Results.
Comparisons are reported in TableÂ 4.
As shown in the table, facilitated by the proposed X-GGM scheme, the baseline VQA model (LXMERT) achieves state-of-the-art OOD and ID performance on VQA-CP v2 â€œOtherâ€.
Besides, compared with all methods utilized UpDn as the baseline VQA model, our method also gains the best OOD and ID performance on â€œOtherâ€.
These results demonstrate the X-GGM scheme is effective for a VQA model to generalize to out-of-distribution samples while preserving its ID performance.

Settings.
Except for LMHÂ (Clark
etÂ al., 2019) and LMÂ (Clark
etÂ al., 2019),
the other methods listed in TableÂ 5 are UB-based and can be further grouped into plain models (models in the third row of TableÂ 5, \eg, BAN4Â (Kim
etÂ al., 2018) and MMNÂ (Chen
etÂ al., 2021)) and transformer-based models (models in the fourth row of TableÂ 5 like MCANÂ (Yu
etÂ al., 2019) and VILLAÂ (Gan
etÂ al., 2020)).
We utilize LXMERT and UpDn as baseline VQA models, and compare the proposed X-GGM scheme with all existing methods on GQA-OOD.
Specifically, RUBiÂ (Cadene etÂ al., 2019), LMHÂ (Clark
etÂ al., 2019) and LMÂ (Clark
etÂ al., 2019) utilize UpDn as their baseline model.
VILLAÂ (Gan
etÂ al., 2020) and MANGOÂ (Li etÂ al., 2020) use LXMERT as the baseline VQA model.
We also reimplement VILLA on GQA-OOD.

Results.
From the comparisons in TableÂ 5, we can observe that benefiting from the OOD generalization ability of X-GGM, the baseline VQA model (LXMERT) trained with our scheme outperforms all other methods on GQA-OOD on the metric Tail.
Although the ID performance (Head) drops by 0.19 relative to the baseline VQA model, it is far smaller than the OOD performance improvement (2.67).
Besides, the baseline VQA model (UpDn) trained with the X-GGM scheme also outperforms these methods utilized UpDn as the baseline VQA model on all metrics, especially on Tail.
These results demonstrate the ability of the proposed X-GGM scheme to OOD generalization and ID preserving.
Unfortunately, the OOD performance improvement on GQA-OOD is not as obvious as that on VQA-CP v2.
It likely because questions of GQA-OOD are semantic compositionality.
The syntax-complex questions weaken the representation ability of ğ’™ğ’™{\bm{x}} while X-GGM also does not explicitly leverage the structured representation of question to enhance ğ’™ğ’™{\bm{x}}.

Comparisons with SoTAs on VQA-CP v2.
TableÂ 7 shows the full comparisons with state-of-the-art debiasing methods on VQA-CP v2.
Compared with both KB-based and UB-based methods, the baseline VQA model (LXMERT) trained with the proposed X-GGM scheme can achieve state-of-the-art OOD and ID performance on VQA-CP v2 â€œOtherâ€, further demonstrating the effectiveness of X-GGM to OOD generalization.
